reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Starts slow but is worth it.
reviews.reviewText: Don't miss out on this book! The research done for this project is impressive and extremely well sited and sourced.The beginning was slow giving maybe a tiny bit too much "background info" but that could be just me because I am very familiar with the subject matter.If you are interested in WWII history or just Pearl Harbor this is for you. I had just recently been to Pearl Harbor and recognized many of the places talked about in this book. The USS Arizona Memorial is a must see- side note.Care was taken when writing anything that wasn't well documented and the writing is honest about those things. The footnotes were great and the way it was split up made it a quick and easy read. Next time I am in Hawaii I am going to go visit the places talked about in this book. It will be so amazing to stand in the footprints of historical giants.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Was going to give it a 3
reviews.reviewText: So to premise my title, the writing was clunky at the the beginning (if you take into account these are new authors, it's easier to get through), the premise of the story is what made me buy the book though. Why I moved it up to 4 is basically the writing righted itself as the book went on. It is a book well worth the read, and as far as the authors go they will progress as was apparent in this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars I haven't gotten to read it yet but my husband...
reviews.reviewText: ... finished it in one night. Now I get a turn. He's a WWII history buff, he's from Oahu, third generation Japanese American, and his Dad, who was hoping to go to France with his cousins was drafted into the Military Intelligence Service (MIS). He tried to tell them he didn't really know Japanese but they looked at his school records and said, "good try". When the Japanese military bombed Pearl Harbor he was on his way to baseball practice. So, the book resonates with my husband on many levels. I think I will enjoy it because it's largely about (I hope) what was going on for the everyday people on Oahu. Yes the heros on each side are all about the military but since they were both living on Oahu I'm hoping to get a feel of what it was like. You may take exception to my calling the Japanese spy hidden in an embassy job a hero, but that's a matter of perspective. He did a dangerous job for his country. To me that makes him a hero.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very interesting story
reviews.reviewText: It is always amazing to keep on learning about Pearl Harbor and how little we are protected from an invasion such as this.It is very scary to read.As an immigrant I ground this book to be a lesson in what life can bring in suffering.I had to watch the Pearl Harbor movie and tie all of these details.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars underground activity prior to Pearl Harbor
reviews.reviewText: The authors follow primarily two subjects prior to the bombing, but seem to tell only part of the story. And it kind of tails off at the end. To be honest I did not learn much from this book. It is an easy read, and for anyone wanting to learn some of the back story prior to the bombing, this may be of value.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 10, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Factual and Well Researched
reviews.reviewText: Harman and his colleague researched carefully and presents a book that gave me a clearer picture of what happened in the Pacific prior and during World War II.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed this book once I realized that it wasn't supposed to be "Combined Fleet Decoded," or "At Dawn We Slept." It's not that kind of war history. It's more personal and gave me a glimpse into how the war changed the population, particularly a select population of Hawaii during the run up to and following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. I know about the intelligence failures and the fumbles. I already know about the battles, the ships, the major players, ups, downs, signals intelligence, victories and mistakes. What I didn't know was how all this had an effect on the Japanese Population in Hawaii, and how a Japanese American would feel with one foot in his non military culture and the other as an intelligence officer for the American Navy. How some people he'd known previously respected him for his service, and others turned their backs on him because of that service. It's personal. But, he's not the only figure that changes and suffers and their stories are just as interesting. It's a thoughtful treatment and one I'm glad to have read along with all of the 4" thick history books on my shelves.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars So much information
reviews.reviewText: Great read with a lot of info that I hadn’t heard, also reinforced some things that I had learned from talking with friends from Hwai and Joan.
I purchased this product for a Christmas gift. The recipient is eager for this read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 30, 2023
reviews.reviewText: Love it from start to finish

reviews.reviewTitle: Personal accounts make it most interesting
reviews.reviewText: Revealing without being preachy. Let's you come to your own conclusions.
This book is very informative. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Watched an interview with Mark Harmon where they discussed this book. My husband is very much into the history of war. I think he will enjoy it.
